rss.title: Justice and Mercy
rss.subtitle: Jesus loves us so we are all going to heaven…Right?

subtitle_detail.value: Jesus loves us so we are all going to heaven…Right?

transcription.full_transcript: Welcome to Catholic Stuff You Should Know, a J-10 initiative. This is, of course, Joe Doman and Father John. Kevin said he should know. We are not yet multilingual. Someday we will do a podcast in Espanol. Actually, Gobel is hilarious in Spanish. He only really knows cuss words and things that he picked up from kind of watching like Telemundo or something like that. And so he just knows how to say really romantic phrases. We had a guy come from Mexico a couple of years ago. who didn't speak any English at all, and Gobel knew, like, maybe eight words in Spanish, and within, like, five minutes had the guy, like, rolling over laughing because he just was there, like, eating ice cream, and Gobel was just like, Yo soy el gordo. When I was in Mexico with him, he, uh... He would just sing Shakira songs and the guys would just die. We stayed at the seminary in Mérida, Mexico. Worst month of my life. We'll tell you about it some other time. But yeah, he was kind of a pop star for the month we were down there. But we don't want to talk about that. El gobel. We don't want to get his... They called him Suncho. Suncho. What does that mean? Marshmallow. Because he was white and soft. So anyways. probably a disgusting uh introduction for you there but it is fantastic joe doman is uh uh on our topic today we're back in uh his bedroom which is a complete disaster it is a disaster i'm sorry yeah sorry mrs doman but uh the truth is uh you know truth i feel like my room is always a reflection of my life like if my room is tidy i think things are pretty going pretty well And if everything is like this, my life's pretty much in shambles. Yeah, that's a good description. It's kind of a disaster with a semblance of the intellectual life, a couple of books, a semblance of a spiritual life, a couple of icons, a semblance of my influence from living here. That's right, your English, I don't know. What do you call those? The Brits. I don't know. Brits? But what I do love is this recliner, which is Phil Barline's grandfather's. And I think I've talked about it on the podcast before. It looks like it's out of a 1970s airliner. Yeah, it's great. It's the best. This is the best thing in your room. I agree. I agree with that. Well, I'm going to London in two days, so we better get to the topic. Sure. Okay, so we today are talking about justice and mercy. Justice and mercy. Yeah, kind of a vague topic, but I think it's kind of important because... You know, we have this idea of we know that God is just, and we know that God is merciful. And so many times we see the two as contradictory. Maybe like the God of the Old Testament is the God who's all, he's all concerned about justice. He's all concerned about, okay, this is what you're doing right, this is what you're doing wrong. When you're doing something wrong, you know, I'm going to send in the nations to totally obliterate you. And I just need to justify my wrath, you know. And then Jesus comes along and he's all about, you know, loving people and mercy. and that's just, I mean, that's not how it is, but that is how people perceive it. And so we know God's merciful. Is God still just? Does that still work out? Or if he's just, like, how does that go with mercy? And Psalm 85 is, you know, I'm sure people have heard this. I think it's in Advent when it talks about mercy and faithfulness have embraced and justice and peace have kissed. So there's this prophecy. that's fulfilled in Christ, that somehow mercy and justice are no longer opposed, but they are embracing. I'm happy you chose this topic because I have a Bible study with some young adults, some young married couples, and I kind of threw this out there, that exact question you had. And it was interesting to hear kind of grappling with it. What did they say? Well, it was basically either justice just gets assimilated into mercy, or, and justice is bad. That was kind of the whole thing. Justice is bad, mercy is good, and mercy kind of sucks it all in. Yeah. But it wasn't reconciled. It didn't make sense. And I said, justice is a good thing, you know? Yeah. I was like, if your parental approach was, you know... for like Polly and his, you know, your brother and his kids, it would be like my parental approach is just straight mercy. All the time. Like I'm never going to be just with my child. They would be disastrous, you know. They'd be like Father Brian Larkin who never had chores but somehow has amazing virtue. So we won't talk about him. He's already been slandered enough on this thing. So how would you describe justice? You want me to give the answer right away? Yeah, yeah. Let's talk about it. Okay. Justice is giving to one that which is their due, right? According to Aristotle. Right. it's one of the four principal cardinal virtues, the hinge virtues, so to speak. Mercy is disclosed in the Jewish world as chesed, right? God's steadfast love. It's the most definitive attribute of God in the Pentateuch. And it works its way all the way through. Old Testament. Old Testament. So mercy, chesed, is there in the Old Testament. I do not desire sacrifice, but mercy. So, I mean, in the Psalms, it's very, very clear. And there's something that awakens in the Jewish mind in the writing of the Psalms after the destruction of Israel, you know, and after the Babylonian exile, that there's this kind of awakening to the need for God's mercy and that justice has been affected and enacted. So they're living where justice for their sins has destroyed the Holy Land. They're in slavery and captivity. And they're asking, what is this? And that's what some of these beautiful prophecies are coming out of, not to get into all the historical, critical, and timing things, but there's something that awakens in them. as a people. A plea for mercy. In the last couple centuries before Christ. It's interesting that you really can't have mercy without a sense of justice either. Like, if you don't have justice, mercy's no longer mercy. Yeah. Like, justice is giving another what they deserve. Right. Giving another what's their due. And mercy is kind of giving them more than they deserve. Right. Sometimes not giving them what they deserve. Or not giving them what they deserve. More love than they deserve. Yeah. But if you, like, from our standpoint, approaching God... if we don't have a sense of justice, then we no longer, mercy no longer makes any sense, because then mercy is just like, oh yeah, God's merciful, so like, God's going to love me, because I just need, it doesn't matter what I do, ultimately, you know, because I know God's going to be merciful, and if we don't have a sense of like, no, actually, my sin, merits death and punishment. You know, like I'm taking my sin, I'm cutting myself off from God. I'm severing that relationship with God, who is the source of my life, who is my strength, who is everything. And the result of that is going to be death and suffering. And if I don't understand that that's kind of what justice demands of sin, then mercy becomes like... Oh yeah, you know, it doesn't matter what I do, because we can't really receive a gift of mercy unless we know what we deserve. Yeah. Because mercy, justice is always what we deserve. Mercy is always a gift. We can never, like, deserve God's mercy. Right. You know, it always has to be bestowed on us freely. And that has to be played out in the sacrament of confession. That's why there has to be contrition, a profound sense of, like, I have to be fully aware of the injustice that I have caused, and thus the justice that I deserve. which is death and condemnation before I repent and receive God's mercy. Yeah. Now, yeah. It's kind of like that parable Christ tells about the king and his servant who owes him all this money. Right. And he's like, okay, you know, you're going to be thrown in prison, your family and everything. And the guy begs on the ground and pleads for mercy. And the king actually has mercy on him. But then when the guy goes out and does the same thing to a fellow servant who owes him some money and he starts choking him and stuff like that. it's clear that he doesn't understand that what the king did for him was a great gift. And he's exacting justice upon, he basically shows by his actions that he didn't understand what a gift it was that he received. He didn't understand how unworthy he was of that. And so when the king sees that, you know, he's totally troubled and basically says, you know, because you didn't receive this gift as mercy, then, you know, mercy is not going to be shown to you. it's just uh it's good it's interesting that we have to we have to kind of understand what our sin means you know in order to receive the gift of mercy and are you ready for the answer what's the you didn't just give the answer what is it no because we still haven't really explained how in a cosmic level justice and mercy you have kissed oh like with christ you ready for this this is give it to me this is baltazar's freaking awesome answer to this question oh i love it And it was really great letting them grapple with this in my Bible study, and being like, all right, you want the answer? I sounded like this, like sage, but everything's stolen from Balthazar. Let's just be honest. He says this, How are justice and mercy reconciled? In Christ, who will become sin, he takes on all of the injustice in the world, and Christ suffers the justice from God the Father. At the moment of his crucifixion, he suffers and in his death, by taking on all of sin, all of injustice, reconciles justice in the world and so is free to dispense with that injustice because it has been reconciled in himself, namely by giving mercy. Does that make sense? So all justice has been accounted for in Christ and thus he has the freedom to disclose mercy. Does that make sense? Like he satisfies the wrath of God. He satisfies, well, not the wrath, but yeah, but the injustice of the world. So how do you, what do you do with this? And what do you do with somebody who's like... Okay, it just sounds like God's really ticked off that there's a bunch of sin, and he's going to get blood either way. So, you know, Jesus is like, okay, have my blood. I mean, in some ways, I think that's how it could sound. What do you do with that? Like, why does God need to have his justice satisfied? Well, because of the covenant that they enter into in the very beginning of creation and in time binds them. It's not just a contract where they can be broken, but it's a covenant that's very binding in the person. So it's about death. It's not about blood primarily. but it's about death is the only act for the injustice and the breaking of the covenant is death because it binds the very life of the person. Yeah, from Deuteronomy, choose life or death. If you do these things, if you are faithful to the covenant, you will live and the land be secure. So all the blood sacrificed in the Old Testament, it's not about God wanting blood sacrifices. This is the nature of the covenant. We've imposed this upon ourselves. So it's not that God wants it. it's that God becomes man to take that on and then die in the stead of that and to reconcile the world to the father and then can dispense mercy as fit. Huh. That's really cool. Isn't that sweet? That is really sweet. Wealthy. My brother David told me this story. David and I were talking about this yesterday. And he has a... he has five kids one two three four david has five kids he they're they're pregnant they're expecting the fifth right now gradually it's wild but they adopted two because they hadn't been having kids for a while but so their two kids they adopted are greg and leah right greg's a little i don't know if he's black or mintskin or what uh and then leah's my goddaughter she's a little mexican girl so cute man um but anyway so david is a he you know when it comes to parenting he's he he gots the justice part down you know he's very clear with this because he's not like you angry or flipping out at them all the time. He's a really great parent, actually. And so, you know, mass goes through and... It was, you know, Greg was great. Leah was a total disaster. That's my goddaughter. Not doing enough prayers, I guess. But, you know, they get back home. And, okay, was Greg good at Mass? Oh, yeah, Greg was great at Mass. You know, he sat still and behaved. Oh, Greg, you know, that's great. You can get your candy. Oh, yeah. It was, you know, got in a big fight about whether or not she was going to have gum out of Mom's purse during the Eucharistic prayer. And all these things. And had a temper tantrum kind of in the back of church. So no, Leah wasn't good at math, so Leah couldn't have candy. And she seemed to not care very much, you know. But Greg's sitting there eating his candy all happy, and then Greg goes up to David and he's like, David, is it okay if I give Leah some of my candy? And he was just like, it was a beautiful moment of Greg being like, okay, I have kind of satisfied the justice here. but uh so i'm because of greg's merit in some sense leah gets to receive and david of course was like yeah of course greg you know if you want to share a kid with leah you can so david was like this is like he's like because for him the whole justice and mercy thing kind of made sense theoretical yeah through theoretically but emotionally he like it just didn't like click until he had this experience of like oh yeah this is how justice and mercy are like actually really tied together because from his standpoint as a parent like yeah you know you these contracts we make actually mean something, you know, and I can't just be, let them go as if, you know, that's just, that's not mercy or justice, like just being a doormat. But there's something beautiful here that was expressed. And just to, I'm sure so many people have this kind of experience in their families where kind of these truths that are written into reality and are part of, you know, our nature.

summarization.results: The discussion explores the relationship between justice and mercy, emphasizing the importance of understanding one's actions to appreciate mercy. It uses examples from the Old Testament, teachings of Jesus, and a parable about a king and his servant to illustrate how justice and mercy can coexist. The dialogue also touches on parenting, highlighting the balance between consequences and compassion in teaching children about behavior.
